headline: Ruben Amorim's quit threats in full as Man Utd sack manager after explosive outburst
body: Ruben Amorim has left Manchester United following his forthright comments after the stalemate with Leeds United on Sunday. The Portuguese manager's comments cast doubt over his position, and this time United's higher-ups decided enough was enough.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club’s leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change," United said in a statement. "This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish.
"The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future. Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."

While results have been underwhelming at times, Amorim's comments have also attracted plenty of scrutiny. Things came to a head after the 1-1 draw at Elland Road, in what would prove to be his final post-match outburst as the man in charge at Old Trafford.
"I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach of Manchester United. That is clear," Amorim told reporters.

"I know that my name is not [Thomas] Tuchel, it's not [Antonio] Conte, it's not [Jose] Mourinho, but I'm the manager of Manchester United. And it's going to be like this for 18 months or when the board decides to change. I'm not going to quit. I will do my job until another guy is coming here to replace me."

We've seen before that a tirade from the boss hasn't always sparked action from up high, including early on when significant pressure surrounded Amorim during his debut season as he made a slow start after succeeding Erik ten Hag. "I know that if we don't win, regardless if they pay the buyout or not, every manager is in danger," he acknowledged in December 2024.

The subsequent month, whilst not explicitly suggesting resignation, he recognised the decline since taking over from Erik ten Hag in the technical area. "In ten games in the Premier League, we won two," he acknowledged following a loss to Brighton.
"Imagine what this is for a fan of Manchester United. Imagine what this is for me. We are getting a new coach that is losing more than the last coach. I have full knowledge of that.

"We are being the worst team maybe in the history of Manchester United. I know that you want headlines, but I'm saying that because we have to acknowledge that and to change that. Here you go, your headlines."

A solid Europa League run took United within 90 minutes of a trophy in Amorim's first season, and victory in the final could have compensated for domestic woes. However, when United were defeated by Spurs in Bilbao, the manager said he was willing to walk away the very next day if that's what the board desired.

"In this moment, I am not going to be here defending myself, [it] is not my style," he said. "I cannot do it, is really hard for me. So I have nothing to show to the fans to say I am going to improve because of this, I had these problems, I will not do nothing.

"In this moment, it's a little bit of faith. So let's see. Like I said before, coming here before in the flash, I am always open. If the board and fans feel that I'm not the right guy, I will go the next day without any conversation about compensation.
"But I will not quit again. I am really confident in my job and, as you can see, I will not change nothing in the way I do things."

United splashed out over the summer, spending more than £200m on Benjamin Sesko, Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and Senne Lammens. However, just weeks into the new season, he was once again hinting at a change in the United dugout after a dismal Carabao Cup defeat to Grimsby Town.
"We played badly for 30 minutes against Fulham. And then that kind of performance, I was really disappointed with everything," Amorim said. "But now it's a new game and I'm focused on the next one.

"If you are in one way, if you have this kind of behaviour, you have to understand that you have things that is good on that type of behaviour, that you have the other side of the coin. So I understand that.

"And again, sometimes I want to quit, sometimes I want to be here for 20 years, sometimes I love to be with my players, sometimes I don't want to be with them. So, again, I need to improve on that. It's going to be hard. But now I'm good with the next one."
He made no apologies for his feelings, stating: "I'm going to say that sometimes I hate my players, sometimes I love my players, sometimes I want to defend my players.

"I think this is my way of doing things and I'm going to be like that. And I felt that in that moment I was so frustrated and [annoyed]. And I know, again, that you have a lot of experienced people talking about the way I should perform with the media, to be more constant, to be more calm. I'm not going to be like that.
"So I'm trying to accept that and I'm going to be who I am. That's why I have the passion that I have."

Amorim's recent remarks have elicited a reaction from Gary Neville, who has observed a shift in the Portuguese manager's attitude of late. "Something has happened in the last week which means that Amorim is starting to unleash a little bit," the former United captain said on the Gary Neville podcast.
"It looks to me that he is not happy with something in the hierarchy. Obviously something is annoying him - he's obviously not feeling the support. He's obviously letting go.
"When you say that you came to the club as a manager, I thought he was appointed as the head coach and quite clearly appointed to coach the team."
It was clear during Amorim's brief tenure that he was not afraid to risk his position. However, the post-Leeds comments proved to be one challenge too many.

body: Manchester United are expected to wait until the summer to appoint a permanent replacement for Ruben Amorim after the club made the decision to SACK him on Monday morning.

Former United midfielder Darren Fletcher is set to take over on an interim basis, with his first game coming in the trip to Burnley on Wednesday. According to The Athletic, the Red Devils are then 'likely' to wait until the end of the season to appoint a permanent successor for Amorim.

The decision to axe Amorim, 40, has been driven by the club's leadership team, including chief executive Omar Berrada and director of football Jason Wilcox, after a breakdown in relationship behind the scenes.
A club statement read: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United. Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club’s leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change. This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish.
"The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future.
"Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."
Speaking after Sunday's draw at Leeds, Amorim hinted that there is tension with those working alongside him, making it evident he views himself as the "manager" and not the "coach" at United.

"It's going to be like this for 18 months or when the board decide to change," Amorim added. "That was my point, I want to finish with that. I’m not going to quit. I will do my job until another guy is coming here to replace me."
Amorim was appointed as Erik ten Hag's permanent replacement at United in November 2024 after Ruud van Nistelrooy enjoyed a successful four-game reign as interim head coach.
The former Sporting CP boss signed a two-and-a-half year deal at Old Trafford and made a fast start to life at the Red Devils, winning two of his opening three matches in charge.

However, United's form ebbed and flowed from that point on, with the Red Devils progressing in the Europa League but faltering in the Premier League. Indeed, Amorim's side dropped into the bottom half in the top flight and ended up finishing 15th - their lowest-ever finish in 50 years.

But, after United reached the Europa League final, Amorim kept his job and was backed in the summer with the club's board spending more than £200million on new players. Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and Benjamin Sesko were the three high-profile players that arrived through the doors.

headline: Manchester United statement in full as reason for Ruben Amorim sacking revealed
body: Manchester United have admitted that the time is right for change after sacking head coach Ruben Amorim. The Portuguese was hired by United in 2024 to replace Erik ten Hag, but has seen his relationship with Old Trafford bosses rapidly deteriorate.
And the final straw came on Sunday after Amorim took aim the hierarchy amid mounting tension over the direction of the club. The Red Devils have now confirmed his departure with a statement released.
It reads: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United. Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club’s leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change. This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish.
"The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future. Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."

headline: Matheus Cunha sends clear transfer message to Man Utd team-mate - 'He needs to understand'
body: Matheus Cunha has told Joshua Zirkzee that he needs to forget about leaving Manchester United and knuckle down to help the team. Zirkzee has been strongly linked with a move to Roma in the January transfer window but has made two telling contributions for United in recent weeks.

The 24-year-old forward has struggled since joining United for £36.5million from Bologna in 2024. He has failed to hold down a place in Ruben Amorim's starting line-up and has agreed to join Roma in January, according to reports in Italy.

However, he started and scored in the 1-1 draw against Wolves last week and came off the bench to set up Cunha's equaliser in the draw at Leeds on Sunday. With Bryan Mbeumo and Amad away at the Africa Cup of Nations, Zirkzee has become more important for United, throwing his potential exit into doubt.

The Dutchman has reportedly met with Roma's sporting director Ricky Massara and has been assured by manager Gian Piero Gasparini that he will fit into their system. But Cunha has pleaded with his team-mate to stay put, swallow his pride and help United during this difficult spell.

"Josh is a pleasure," he told Match of the Day. "I feel like he has a lot of quality. Of course, his situation is not easy, but he has everything to change the situation. We need him. He needs to understand this and then everyone can count on him.
"But yeah, we are here to push him. And I think after the goal last week and the assist today, I think it will give him confidence to be more with us and then understand more his role in the team."

Amorim's view of Zirkzee was evident in the starting line-up he named at Elland Road on Sunday, with the forward left on the bench alongside a whole host of academy players. headline: Zinedine Zidane's nine-word reason why he wouldn't want Man Utd job as Ruben Amorim sacked
body: Manchester United could be disappointed in their search for a Ruben Amorim successor if they go after Zinedine Zidane. That's after the World Cup-winner already gave a damning answer concerning a potential contract at Old Trafford.

Amorim, 40, has been sacked as United boss after disappointing 1-1 draw away to Leeds on Sunday. In the aftermath, he suggested he'll leave when his contract expires in 18 months, insisting he came to United "to be the manager, not the coach," and took aim at certain board members to focus on their jobs. However, his departure has come much earlier, with the decision made on Monday morning.

United haven't budged from sixth in the Premier League, but there are only four points between them and Crystal Palace in 14th. The campaign is reminiscent of the 2021/22 campaign that saw them finish sixth before Erik ten Hag took over that summer.

It was around the same time Zidane, who has been a free agent since leaving Real Madrid in 2021, gave a direct hint at his prospects of taking over in Manchester. And despite being highly desirable candidate for the position, he nodded to one key impasse that could stop any chance of the switch.

Speaking to L'Equipe at the time, he gave a nine-word response when addressing United rumours specifically, which may suggest he'll never work in the Premier League: "I understand English, but I don't fully master it."

He continued: "I know that there are coaches who go to clubs without speaking the language, but I work in a different way. Many elements come into play in order to win, it is a global context. I know what I need to win."

From that, one might assume Zidane wouldn't be comfortable taking a job in England unless he was fluent in the language. The Frenchman spent the last five years of his playing career at Real before joining the club's advisory board and then climbing the coaching ranks.

It resulted in one of the most prolific managerial spells in history, claiming three Champions League titles, two league wins and two FIFA Club World Cups in only four-and-a-half seasons. United could only dream of such success in their current mould, though their issues run far deeper than coaching selection alone.

Zidane's former France team-mate and fellow 1998 World Cup-winner Emmanuel Petit has since revealed his old colleague has spent time learning English. Speaking to DAZN Bet in 2023, Petit suggested this means Zidane has "changed his mind about managing a team in England," though there's nothing concrete to suggest as much.

There's also the major barrier of a certain vacancy soon to open up at the France helm. Didier Deschamps' highly successful run as boss of Les Bleus will end after the 2026 World Cup, and it's widely believed Zidane is being lined up as his heir.

One can understand why taking control of his national side is a far more attractive prospect than attempting to resuscitate United. However, it may work in Amorim's favour if arguably the best free-agent coaching option on the market doesn't want his job.

From a United perspective, the club needs captain Fernandes back as soon as possible, which Amorim has hinted could be this month. The next obstacle is a trip to Turf Moor to face Burnley on Wednesday, where anything but three points would only encourage speculation Amorim is bound for the exit.

headline: Ruben Amorim torn apart by Jamie Carragher just hours before Man Utd sacking
body: Former Liverpool defender Jamie Carragher hammered Manchester United boss Ruben Amorim, saying the Portuguese head coach is a 'barely competent' top-flight manager just hours before his axing. The comments come after the United boss dropped an explosive post-match press conference following the draw with Leeds United, hitting out at United's sporting director, Jason Wilcox, and former defender Gary Neville.

Amorim said he wanted to be the manager of the team, not a head coach, wanting control of every department, including scouting. He then namedropped Gary Neville and called on Wilcox to do his job, while Amorim did his own.
However, that proved to be his downfall as the Portuguese boss was ruthlessly axed by United, who confirmed the news in a statement on Monday morning.
It read: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United. Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club’s leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change. This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish.
"The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future. Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."

"It started to look like maybe he was getting somewhere moving to a back four, he went back to five at the back against Wolves and it brought possibly one of the worst performances of the season from a team. No matter what it is, I don't think he is in any position whatsoever to be questioning the people who appointed him.
"He's not good enough. He's not good enough to be Manchester United's manager. He's barely competent enough to be a Premier League manager right now. That's not me being disrespectful to Amorim.

"He's been there well over 12 months now and I think almost all managers in the Premier League who are managing different clubs at different ends of the table would look at Manchester United and think 'I'd get more points than that.' This is a guy who said at one stage this is possibly the worst Manchester United team in history. He's managing it."

Responding to the idea that Amorim had not been backed, Carragher said: "He's been more than backed. He couldn't have had too many complaints if the club parted company with him in the summer, with how poor it was last season.

"They then went into the market and spent a lot of money. I'm sure he was heavily involved in that. He's playing a system that is not in the traditions of Man United, so there was no way they could go out and recruit all the attacking players, and the wing backs and perhaps the centre backs.

"It was going to be a long term plan in terms of windows. He can't be complaining now about the funds in January. Manchester United spent a huge amount in the summer. Don't forget, they had no Champions League football, no European football and a lot of that was down to him.

"Let's not forget, when he was brought in, the idea was to get them back to Champions League football. They were four points off the Champions League when he came in. They finished 15th. So when you talk about the lack of funds, that was down to him and the team, and there's no way he's going to get everything he wants in one window."

He continued: "Of course they need need better players but it can't come in one window. He - or the club - decided to go with attacking players, they could have maybe gone with one midfielder, one attacking player, one wing-back but they didn't and maybe they'll come in future windows.

"But the people he seems to be having a go at - (chief executive) Omar Berrada and Jason Wilcox - they're the ones who brought him in and were probably the ones who were fighting in the summer to keep him in a job. I'm sure Jim Ratcliffe is looking at the situation and thinking you've brought in a guy, he doesn't play the way Manchester United have in the past and the results are horrendous."

Carragher compared Amorim's comments to Enzo Maresca's recent outburst at Chelsea and subsequent departure from Stamford Bridge. He said: "This could be over very quickly. But Maresca was in a much stronger position to challenge his board and the owner than Amorim.
"He won the Club World Cup. He got the team into the Champions League. He did everything he was asked to do last season. I still didn't think it was acceptable to challenge the people above him.
"Amorim is in no position whatsoever to speak like that. As I said, he's a barely competent Premier League manager so far on what he has shown."
United will now working to hire a new permanent manager with Oliver Glasner one of the early leading contenders.

headline: Gary Neville hits back at Ruben Amorim with immediate Man Utd reply after manager rant
body: Gary Neville has waded in on Ruben Amorim's "bizarre" post-match press conference comments after the Manchester United boss seemed to hint that the club and he would go their own ways when his contract expires.

The United boss cast doubt over his future at Old Trafford following the 1-1 draw at Leeds United on Sunday. Amorim had hinted at issues behind the scenes in his press conference on Friday before escalating the issue at Elland Road.

"Guys, to stop with that, I noticed that you receive selective information about everything," he said. "I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach of Manchester United. And that is clear. I know that my name is not Tuchel, it's not Conte, it's not Mourinho, but I'm the manager of Manchester United.

"And it's going to be like this for 18 months, or when the board decides to change. So that was my point, I want to finish with that. I'm not going to quit. I will do my job until the other guy is coming here to replace me."

Amorim also repeated that everyone would move on when his contract expires in 18 months. He also suggested that he had been promised more power to reshape the club, while also name-checking Neville in the process.

"I just want to say that I'm going to be the manager of this team, not just the coach," he said. "And I was really clear on that. And that is going to finish in 18 months and then everyone is going to move on. That was the deal.

"That is my job, not to be a coach. If people cannot handle the Gary Neville and the criticism of everything, we need to change the club. No, guys, I just want to say that I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach. And every department, the scouting department, the sports director, needs to do their job. I will do mine for 18 months and then we move on."

Following Amorim's rant, Neville was asked about his thoughts on the matter on the Gary Neville podcast from the Etihad Stadium. "Some bizarre comments around, 'I'm a manager, not a head coach'. I just said about Maresca, once you start this game-playing in your press conferences, something is obviously annoying him, he's not feeling the support and he's letting go," he said.

"To say that you've come to the club as a manager, I thought he was appointed head coach of the football club and appointed to coach the team. Manager is a title that we don't see anymore. I don't know what Pep Guardiola is at Manchester City.

"Manager suggests that he's saying that he wants to manage more than just the training ground performance. He wants to overlook other parts of the club. They have a greater say on other parts of the club, like recruitment, academy, style of play and how the club go about their pre-season friendlies.

"He's suggesting, maybe, that he needs to be given the ability to manage more departments of the club. I've not seen the press conference at all, they've just been sent to me by the staff producer, but [he said] about other people doing their job in their department.

"Again, that would suggest that he's not happy with something. Something's happened there in the last week with the quotes that are coming out, that mean that Ruben Amorim is now starting to unleash and as Maresca did.

"It's not quite that, but it's something similar in a way that it's not explicit what it means, but everyone's having to read inbetween the lines. It looks to me that he's not happy about something in the hierarchy.

"He's mentioned my name in it as well, apparently. That's the sort of thing that managers tend to do towards difficult periods, they have a go at pundits. No problem with that whatsoever. I've actually been quite supported of Manchester United's performances against Bournemouth, Aston Villa and Newcastle.

"I thought they were very good. I couldn't be supportive the other night against Wolves, if that's what he's referring to. It wasn't right the other night and you have to say that. It wasn't right against 10-men Everton.

"I am going to call out when I see things that aren't right because that's my job. That aside, the bigger problem isn't about what he said about me, matter of fact, it's not a problem at all, it's more the problem of what he's saying is happening behind the scenes."

headline: Leeds confirm fan tragically died ahead of Man Utd match as club release statement
body: Leeds have confirmed that a supporter tragically died at Elland Road on Sunday ahead of their game against Manchester United. The two teams met for a Premier League match which ended in a 1-1 draw.

No further details about the person who died or the circumstances of their passing have been released.

Leeds took the lead shortly after the hour mark, as Brenden Aaronson opened the scoring. Matheus Cunha replied for the visitors three minutes later and nothing could separate the sides before the final whistle.

"I think we controlled Leeds quite well, a team that is really strong on set-pieces and with second balls, they are really quick in front and I think we controlled it well. headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United have sacked Ruben Amorim after power struggle claim and new demands
body: Manchester United insist Ruben Amorim was sacked due to a lack of progress on the pitch and have denied there was a power struggle going on at Old Trafford, despite Amorim bringing those tensions into the open over the last week.

Amorim was sacked on Monday morning, less than 19 hours after a remarkable press conference at Elland Road in which he demanded more power and told director of football Jason Wilcox to "do his job". Tensions between Amorim and members of the football leadership team, including Wilcox and director of recruitment Christopher Vivell, have become public in recent weeks and Amorim laid them bare at Elland Road.

His stunning remarks left nobody in any doubt that were issues behind the scenes at Old Trafford. Amorim's job came under immediate scrutiny and after what was essentially a 'back me or sack me' plea, his 63-game reign was brought to an end on Monday.

But United sources insist that the decision was made solely on results and denied there had been any power struggles or that Amorim had laid down an ultimatum demanding more power. They insist the 40-year-old maintained the 'unwavering support' of everyone within the club but there hadn't been enough progress for him to continue in the role.

Amorim had been frustrated at being told there was no money to spend in January and was keen to add a midfielder to his squad, with United initially showing interest in attacker Antoine Semenyo before tightening the purse strings.

The decision was made to sign three attacking players last summer, in Bryan Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko, as well as goalkeeper Senne Lammens, and United insist Amorim was on board with that recruitment plan and happy with the decision to strengthen the attack over the midfield.

In his press conference after the Leeds draw, Amorim had demanded to be the manager at United rather than the coach, even though his job title since his appointment in November 2024 was head coach. United have no plans to change that structure and their next appointment is likely to have to accept the same job title.

United sources point out that the £250million spent since Amorim's arrival made the club one of the highest spenders in the Premier League in that time. Although the team have shown signs of improvement this season and sit sixth in the Premier League, the decision has been made to axe Amorim to give the squad a better chance of qualifying for the Champions League next season.

headline: MARSHALL: One person is coming of Ruben Amorim debacle with credit - and he's already left Man United
body: Dan Ashworth would have known the end was coming at Manchester United when he was marched through the press conference room soon after the defeat to Nottingham Forest in December 2024. This was a public sacking for a figure who had gone from hero to zero in five months in the eyes of Sir Jim Ratcliffe.

Ashworth was the man Ratcliffe called "one of the best sporting directors in the world" during protracted negotiations with Newcastle to lure him to Old Trafford. However, within months, relations had soured. It reflected poorly on Ratcliffe at the time and now, with the dismissal of Ruben Amorim, the manager over whom Ashworth had so many reservations, even worse.

Ratcliffe could have picked up the phone to anyone in the game and been told Ashworth was a structures guy, not the kind of sporting director who would hand over a list of the five most highly rated 30-something coaches in Europe. He was a sensible appointment for a club that needed reshaping. But his caution over the appointment of Amorim ultimately did for him.

Ashworth could see the problems coming of parachuting in a head coach mid-season who had a distinctive playing style. This wasn't a squad built for Amorim's 3-4-2-1 and neither did United have the cash to transform it.

It was a sensible, pragmatic, common-sense approach, but didn't fit with the bravado and excitement of everyone else involved. Amorim was the shiny new toy, the up-and-coming coach who had built an excellent reputation at Sporting and when he guided his old club to a 4-1 win against Manchester City in November 2024, Old Trafford had fallen head over heels.

In hindsight, now that the Portuguese has been unceremoniously sent packing after just 14 months at the helm, the concerns Ashworth highlighted were correct. Amorim might still be an excellent coach (or manager), and with the right players, his system might be a success somewhere. But these weren't conditions he was ever likely to encounter at United and it's been proven.

Instead, he played his system without the tools to do and his team became too predictable as a result. Most of the best managers in the game have a fairly distinctive style of play, but it is often unstoppable because they have the players to execute it. Not at Old Trafford. Not for Amorim.
When his bosses were telling him to change the system and that there was no money, it was hard to see how he would ever survive and create a successful team. That chance is now gone.

Director of football Jason Wilcox and chief executive Omar Berrada are damaged by the episode, their reputations at the club linked to Amorim's appointment. This was their big call and it has gone horribly wrong.

It will take some explaining away when there was at least one senior figure in the building sounding the alarm bells. They ignored that warning and pressed ahead anyway. The surprise is the nature of the unravelling. less than 14 months on, not that it happened.
So now, does Ratcliffe trust Wilcox and Berrada to get the next appointment right? Ratcliffe himself has hitched himself to the success of a head coach he likes.

The 73-year-old was desperate for his first appointment to be the right one, but that has not happened. Now, the past 14 months feel like a waste. United are no further on than when Erik ten Hag was sacked - and the Dutchman won trophies, in fairness to him.

Ashworth might have advocated an appointment considered safer, maybe even a little more boring. He would have been panned for pushing Gareth Southgate's credentials and Thomas Frank has struggled with the step up from Brentford to Tottenham. But in pointing out the pitfalls of going for Amorim, he could see what was likely to happen.

headline: RAILSTON: Three players' reactions to Benjamin Sesko highlighted a Manchester United problem
body: Manchester United drew 1-1 with Leeds in the Premier League on Sunday afternoon. Leeds headed into the game unbeaten in six league matches, and they drew first blood against their rivals.
Brenden Aaronson opened the scoring in the 62nd minute after sloppy play from United, but Ruben Amorim introduced Joshua Zirkzee and the change immediately paid off.
Zirkzee provided an assist for Cunha, whose goal ensured the points were shared. Here are the moments you might have missed:
Amorim outburst

"We are losing because of the second balls," said Amorim last month, so it wasn't a surprise to see the 40-year-old lash out on the touchline when United failed to win a second ball against Leeds. Benjamin Sesko lost the initial aerial duel for the header, despite his height advantage, and Patrick Dorgu didn't react quickly enough to pounce on the second ball.

Amorim responded by lashing out. He aggressively waved his arms in frustration, which suggested he felt Sesko and Dorgu had to do better in that moment. Dorgu was not in the correct starting position to win the ball because he is not used to playing as a right-side No.10. Amorim was frustrated, but he decided to play the defender out of position.

Sesko had no excuses, however, as he should be winning most headers at 6ft 4in. The Slovenia international didn't offer much off the ball and must improve in that area, especially when he's not scoring.
Hands on their heads
And the reaction from Sesko's teammates when he missed a chance from close range with 15 minutes remaining was telling. Cunha, Luke Shaw and Casemiro had their hands on their heads.
Zirkzee played the ball into the box after a clever pass from Cunha, but the 22-year-old volleyed wide and squandered the type of chance that top Premier League strikers put away.
Premier League games are decided by fine margins. The standard in the top-flight has increased - the table is tighter than ever - and it's crucial to capitalise on chances when they are presented.
United would have returned to Manchester with a 2-1 victory if Sesko had buried it.
Zirkzee's reaction

It was noticeable that the only two senior outfield substitutes, Joshua Zirkzee and Tyrell Malacia, wore their long winter coats during the warm-up, while the remainder of the substitutes (who were all players from the academy) kicked the ball around wearing just their sweatshirts.

It was a freezing cold day in West Yorkshire, the type of weather that would make any senior professional who is hardly playing question their future. As it happens, Zirkzee already wants to leave, and he might have been thinking about a return to Italy while he warmed up with academy players.
Amorim preferred to play Dorgu, a defender, over Zirkzee at Elland Road, just a week after hooking Zirkzee at half-time to give Jack Fletcher his third appearance for the first team.

Zirkzee would have felt demoralised by the team selection, but he channelled his frustration in the right way when he came on from the bench, immediately providing an excellent assist. The pass into the box to Cunha was perfectly-weighted, and Zirkzee's contribution didn't go unnoticed as the Brazilian celebrated because Lisandro Martinez sprinted to embrace him.
Berrada and Wilcox spotted

Sir Alex Ferguson was spotted sitting behind Omar Berrada and Jason Wilcox at Elland Road. Amorim has previously spoken about his warm relationship with the Ineos' decision-makers, but there was a hint of tension when the United boss spoke at his press conference ahead of facing Leeds.

Amorim appeared to be concerned that conversations had not taken place about new signings in the January window, and he was unusually spiky for a pre-match press conference. Berrada and Wilcox oversaw the appointment of Amorim, and it will reflect badly on the pair if he is sacked. Sir Jim Ratcliffe wants United to be 'best in class' - but they couldn't even claim a win against Leeds.
'Biggest game of the season'

Leeds-United is a historic rivalry. Of course, United fans are always desperate to beat Leeds, but this is the game of the season for Leeds fans, a point that was was proved by a comment from a Leeds fan sitting next to the press box.

"But it's our biggest game of the season," the fan said when a steward asked him to take his seat instead of standing up. The Elland Road stadium announcer introduced United as the 'red side' before kick-off, and every United player was booed as their names were out. Vitriol poured out from every stand in the ground, with Leeds fans chanting "scum, scum, scum" and "get into them, f*** them up". That was followed by "stand up if you hate Man U".
The raucous atmosphere only lasted for 15 minutes, though. United managed the game intelligently in the first half, and you could have heard a pin drop when half-time arrived.

headline: Rio Ferdinand reveals Man United training ground visit changed his view on Ruben Amorim sack
body: Rio Ferdinand has given his verdict on Manchester United's decision to sack Ruben Amorim, explaining how a recent training ground visit sparked feelings that it was the beginning of the end of his tenure. The club announced on Monday morning that they had made the decision to part ways with the 40-year-old, despite improved performances at Old Trafford.

A statement from the club read: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United. Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club’s leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change. This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish.
The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future. Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."

Reacting to the news, Reds legend Ferdinand explained how he is surprised by the decision. Speaking on his Rio Ferdinand Presents YouTube channel, the former centre-half said: "They have sacked him, they have sacked him!"
He added: "I didn’t anticipate this when I woke up this morning that Ruben Amorim would be getting the sack. He was not in the four or five managers I thought would be getting the sack next.

"I am surprised but when you look at his record, in black and white, I’m not surprised. I think that has been definitive and the reason it’s been so sharp overnight [speaking out]. Two managers have spoken out against the hierarchy now and been sacked immediately. But his record is the worst of any United manager since Sir Alex Ferguson.”

However, Ferdinand also added that a training ground visit sparked concerns that it was the beginning of the end for Amorim at Manchester United. He added: "I saw his last two press conferences and was thinking something isn’t right here.

"This guy’s best trait and one of the most likeable things about him has been his ability to be quite punchy and upbeat in his press conferences. He had quite a jovial way about himself. The last two he did looked depressing. I didn’t say it because I get the ability to go into the training ground and see people and whatnot at times.

"The last time I went there to interview Bruno [Fernandes], I saw the manager and we had a little chat for five or 10 minutes. He’s [usually] warm, he spends time with you, he’s an open book. When I went there the last time, I noticed immediately that there was a coldness about him. There was a real difference to what I’d seen before.

"Now I look back with hindsight, things were starting to cook before Christmas. This isn’t just an overnight thing, I don’t think, in terms of his dialogue with the hierarchy and the way he’s been feeling about things. I felt this coldness that we’ve seen in the last two press conferences. I saw it in him.

"The training ground felt good and the vibe around the players. But he just felt a little bit distant. When I saw him last time he was a very different human being. I was thinking it was the wear and tear of a long, hard season and the pressure was getting to him a little bit, maybe he’d woken up on the wrong side of the bed. But now, looking back, this has been cooking before Christmas. One hundred per cent."

It comes as United currently sit sixth in the Premier League standings with eight wins, seven draws and five losses to show for their efforts - a major improvement on their 15th-place finish for 2024/25.

However, the Portuguese tactician has faced scrutiny for comments this season, the latest coming in the wake of a 1-1 draw with Leeds United on Sunday. Speaking after the trip to Elland Road, Amorim said: "I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach of Manchester United. That is clear.

"I know that my name is not [Thomas] Tuchel, it's not [Antonio] Conte, it's not [Jose] Mourinho, but I'm the manager of Manchester United. And it's going to be like this for 18 months or when the board decides to change. I'm not going to quit. I will do my job until another guy is coming here to replace me."
In the wake of Amorim's exit, Fletcher will take the reins of the first-team for Wednesday's Premier League clash with Burnley.
Whether the club will opt to continue with the U18s head coach for the rest of the season, or if they will appoint a more experienced top flight manager remains to be seen at present.

headline: MARSHALL: Amorim has started a civil war at Manchester United - there is only one winner
body: For five minutes, Ruben Amorim's post-match press conference at Elland Road had been mundane. He had defended Benjamin Sesko and hailed an improved performance. Then, in less than 90 seconds of answers, he pulled the pin on the grenade and started a civil war at Manchester United.

The question now is, where does he go from here? Amorim insisted he wouldn't quit. His comments had a back me or sack me vibe and three wins since October would make the former a surprise. The 40-year-old has begun a power struggle and calling out director of scouting Christopher Vivell and director of football Jason Wilcox made clear where the manager believes the fault lines lie.

There had been talk of a rupture in the corridors of power for a few weeks and now Amorim has laid it all out in the open. He began his explosive comments by telling the media that we "receive selective information about everything."

So what was he talking about? It would be a safe bet to say that he had been riled by a story in the Daily Mail over the weekend that exposed concerns from Vivell and Wilcox about the playing style and Amorim's back three system. His brief flirtation with a back four in December has been shelved but where it came from in the first place is a bit of a mystery.

Amorim had been so steadfast in his refusal to ever move away from a system he had used throughout his managerial career that his volte-face came as a surprise. It is telling that he has abandoned it as quickly as he rolled it out. Wilcox is concerned about United's predictability in Amorim's set-up, and it is clear that opposition teams find it easy to prepare for.

If Amorim was considering meeting Wilcox halfway, then he has clearly changed his mind. Being told there would be no money in January has been the final straw. United were prepared to spend £65million on Antoine Semenyo and despite seeing the 25-year-old opt for Manchester City, they have made it clear he wasn't being signed to play left wing-back.

Having missed out on Semenyo, that cash has now been put back in the safe. Amorim's grumbles on transfer business have been building for a couple of weeks. Before the Wolves game, he was asked about recruitment, and in hindsight, his comments hint at the division that was brewing behind the scenes.

"I have one idea, Jason and the board have another idea, but every decision we make, we need to reach a common ground," he said. "That is really important because you don't need to make everything for the manager because the manager can change, and then you need to change everything.
"But you also need to understand that the manager understands the way of playing. If you don't reach common ground, the player would not come, so we just try to do that."
With everything that has happened since, that line about the manager understanding the way of playing looks like the first of many messages delivered to his bosses in the last week or so.

He raised the stakes on Friday with his refusal to answer why he had come to the conclusion that he wouldn't get the time or money to play a "perfect 3-4-3"; however, his response to his questioner, "You are a smart guy," was a clear hint that the conclusion was obvious.

And for those left in any doubt, Amorim shredded it all on Sunday. He was appointed as head coach in November 2024, but has now decided that the job title isn't good enough for him. He wants the power afforded to Thomas Tuchel, Antonio Conte and Jose Mourinho, despite not having the CV to match.

"I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach of Manchester United. And that is clear," he said. "I know that my name is not Tuchel, it's not Conte, it's not Mourinho, but I'm the manager of Manchester United.

"And it's going to be like this for 18 months, or when the board decides to change. So that was my point, I want to finish with that. I'm not going to quit. I will do my job until the other guy is coming here to replace me.

"I just want to say that I'm going to be the manager of this team, not just the coach. And I was really clear on that. And that is going to finish in 18 months and then everyone is going to move on. That was the deal. That is my job, not to be a coach.

"If people cannot handle the Gary Neville and the criticism of everything, we need to change the club. No, guys, I just want to say that I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach. And every department, the scouting department, the sports director needs to do their job. I will do mine for 18 months and then we move on."
This clearly isn't someone angling for a new contract. Amorim will see out his 18 months, but it seems he is saying that if this structure remains, he will leave then.

He is unlikely to last another 18 months, however. Wilcox is right to have doubts over Amorim's tactical approach, but the uncomfortable reality for this United structure under Sir Jim Ratcliffe is that they have bet the house on the Portuguese. If he fails, where does it leave them?

In a way, Wilcox, Vivell, Amorim and even chief executive Omar Berrada will now look to Ratcliffe for the next move. The minority owner hasn't been to a game since the 4-1 win against Wolves on December 8 and things have clearly changed since then.
Ratcliffe can be unpredictable. He likes Amorim and admires his straight-talking approach, but there is shooting from the hip and then there is this. It was unfriendly fire.

The 73-year-old billionaire showed his ruthless streak when getting rid of Dan Ashworth after just five months. That was put down to a personality clash, but Ratcliffe was frustrated that Ashworth was raising concerns about the appointment of Amorim. There is more than a degree of irony to that now.

So what will Ratcliffe do next? He was talking of giving Amorim three years in October, but that now looks impossible. It's hard to see how Wilcox and Amorim can continue to coexist for much longer. It wouldn't be out of character for Ratcliffe to look to end this one way or another this week.

Perhaps results will dictate what happens next, at least to a degree. Amorim will face the media at Carrington on Tuesday, and it feels inconceivable that he won't have met Wilcox for showdown talks before then. Can they come up with a New Year's truce? If they don't, then Amorim will badly need a win at Burnley.
His hand isn't exactly strong at the moment, but then he has never been one to bite his tongue either.

headline: MARSHALL: Ruben Amorim hints at Man United exit date in explosive comments after Leeds draw
body: Ruben Amorim has cast doubt on his future as Manchester United head coach and hinted he will walk away when his contract expires in 18 months. The 40-year-old demanded to be seen as the manager at Old Trafford, rather than head coach, even though the latter is his official title since being appointed by Ineos in November 2024.

Amorim hinted at issues behind the scenes in his press conference on Friday and escalated his attack on the structure in place after United had actually played well to earn a point in a 1-1 draw at Leeds United.

He was asked why he had seemed so downbeat on Friday and responded with demands for more power, suggesting he was promised that when recruited from Sporting. Amorim said ahead of the game he expected no new signings this month and during his answer at Elland Road he called on director of football Jason Wilcox to do his job.

"Guys, to stop with that, I noticed that you receive selective information about everything," he said. "I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach of Manchester United. And that is clear. I know that my name is not Tuchel, it's not Conte, it's not Mourinho, but I'm the manager of Manchester United.

"And it's going to be like this for 18 months, or when the board decides to change. So that was my point, I want to finish with that. I'm not going to quit. I will do my job until the other guy is coming here to replace me."

Amorim repeated several times that everyone would move on when his contract expires and suggested he had been promised more power to reshape the culture of a club that has been underperforming for far too long.

"I just want to say that I'm going to be the manager of this team, not just the coach," he said. "And I was really clear on that. And that is going to finish in 18 months and then everyone is going to move on. That was the deal.

"That is my job, not to be a coach. If people cannot handle the Gary Neville and the criticism of everything, we need to change the club. No, guys, I just want to say that I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach. And every department, the scouting department, the sports director needs to do their job. I will do mine for 18 months and then we move on."

headline: Alejandro Garnacho immediately rubs salt in Ruben Amorim's wounds after Man United sacking
body: Former Manchester United forward Alejandro Garnacho has reacted to Ruben Amorim's sacking by 'liking' a social media post. The Portuguese tactician was relieved of his duties after 14 months in charge, following his incendiary comments made after their 1-1 draw with Leeds United.

The 21-year-old has aimed one final parting dig at his former manager despite completing his unceremonious departure from Old Trafford in the summer, following a breakdown in his relationship with Amorim. The winger was one of several United players who were deployed to the bomb squad and told to look for another club.
Months after Garnacho's move to the capital, Amorim was sacked by United following the explosive comments that outlined bubbling tensions behind the scenes.

In a statement, the club wrote: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United. Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club’s leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change. This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish.
"The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future. Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."
Fabrizio Romano posted the news on social media, namely his Instagram account, and among those was the former United winger.

The Argentinian was sold to Premier League rivals Chelsea in the summer after falling out of favour with the Portuguese head coach. Garnacho cut a frustrated figure in the latter stages of his United career as he was left in the cold for key matches, including the Europa League final in May.
Garnacho was recently asked whether he regretted the decision to leave old Trafford, he said: "No. No. Sometimes in life you need to change things to take a step forward or improve as a player.
"It was the right moment, and the right club. So it was an easy decision."
In May, Amorim told Garnacho that he would be allowed to join a new club in the summer after being left out of the final game of the season against Aston Villa.
Garnacho had voiced his frustrations towards the decision to leave him out of the starting line-up for their cup final defeat in Europe.
In response, the "He is a Manchester United player that is not in the squad today, but he continues to be a Manchester United player."
Darren Fletcher will now take interim charge of United for their encounter with relegation-threatened Burnley on Wednesday (8.15pm kick-off).
Amorim departs Old Trafford with United in sixth, three points off Liverpool in the Champions League places.

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United player ratings vs Leeds as Matheus Cunha and Joshua Zirkzee good but one 5/10
body: Manchester United earned a hard-fought point at Elland Road after overcoming a lively atmosphere and a confident Leeds team to edge proceedings. A poor game came to life when Leeds took the lead out of nowhere. Some slack United defending allowed Brenden Aaronson to latch on to a Pascal Struijk clearance and finish past Senne Lammens.
United were unfortunate to be behind on the balance of play and found an equaliser within three minutes. Joshua Zirkzee's pass sent Matheus Cunha away and he finished smartly.
Here are how the players rated at Elland Road:
Senne Lammens: Could possibly have done better for the goal but two smart second-half saves from Gudmundsson and Okafor and his distribution was sound under pressure. 6
Leny Yoro: Couple of nervy moments as we have come to expect. Can be too easy to get in behind down the right side at the moment. 6
Ayden Heaven: One well-timed tackle in the box when at first it had looked a reckless move. Good in possession but caught napping for the goal. 6
Lisandro Martinez: Passing was good and showed plenty of aggression when defending. Back on the left of the back three and clearly more suited to that role. 7
Diogo Dalot: Some slack moments in possession and too casual in giving it away for the first goal. Right flank exposed at times. 6
Manuel Ugarte: One of his best games of the season, with conditions to suit. Didn't do loads in possession but was good without the ball and set a really combative tone. 7
Casemiro: Better on the ball than Ugarte and also competed well. Midfield looked like a potential weakness for United but it didn't really work out that way. 7
Luke Shaw: Corners were dangerous and made one excellent defensive header. Back in a position he hasn't played for several years but put up a good showing. 7
Patrick Dorgu: Being moved about all over the place at the moment and not helping him. Screwed one first-half chance just wide. 6
Matheus Cunha: United's best player. Carried the fight in the first and clearly the best player on the pitch. Deserved his goal and looked lively. 8
Benjamin Sesko: Amorim on his case over hold-up play early on. Involved in the goal but poor centre-forward play to be offside for a bad header and then missed a good chance to win it. 5
Substitutes
Joshua Zirkzee: A rare Amorim sub that showed intent and it paid off. Good ball to set up Cunha for the equalising goal and had some good moments as a No.10. 7
Subs not used: Bayindir, Fredricson, Kukonki, Malacia, Mantato, J. Fletcher, T. Fletcher, Lacey.

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United have been handed a January opportunity they can't afford to miss
body: The year ended with a whimper for Manchester United. A 1-1 draw with Wolves on Tuesday night continued a dire recent run at Old Trafford and set alarm bells ringing again about the progress of this team under Ruben Amorim.

Dropping points against a side with 16 defeats and two draws from their first 18 games wasn't a good look. Amorim refused to use the absence of key players to injuries and international call-ups as an excuse, and any team United put out should be capable of beating this Wolves team.

However, it is true that Amorim's resources are currently stretched. The damage done was also eased by other results. Chelsea dropped points at home to Bournemouth, just as United did in December, and then sacked head coach Enzo Maresca on New Year's Day.

Elsewhere on the first day of 2026, Liverpool lumbered to a goalless draw with Leeds at Anfield. Arne Slot's side have picked up better results recently, but they still aren't playing well and are having to grind out results every week.

With the top three of Arsenal, Manchester City and Aston Villa edging clear, it might be that two from three of United, Chelsea and Liverpool will qualify for the Champions League, presuming the Premier League can land that fifth spot once again for next season.

There will be honourable mentions for Sunderland and Everton, who have had excellent first halves of the season, while the league is so congested that only five points separate Chelsea in fifth from Brighton in 14th. A good run of form could propel any number of clubs into the mix.

For United, they would probably have taken this at the halfway stage of the campaign. They are sixth, behind Chelsea only on goal difference and three points shy of Liverpool. Qualification for the Champions League is attainable this season.

The concern is that a woeful run at home might look costly come the end of the season. They have taken three points from home games against Everton, West Ham, Bournemouth and Wolves. The first of those played with 10 men for the best part of 80 minutes and the other three were - and still are - in poor form.

United will have to improve to make the top five, but possibly not by much. Liverpool still look like a flawed team, and Chelsea are unpredictable. The departure of Maresca might change things, but a young and inexperienced squad will be tested in the second half of the campaign.

Amorim's side haven't taken advantage of a kinder fixture list recently and now face Manchester City and Arsenal in January, but having put themselves in a position to achieve what was the primary objective this season, they should consider rolling the dice this month.

Interest in Antoine Semenyo waned when it became clear he wanted to move to Manchester City, but United's willingness to do a deal suggests there is money available to improve the squad. The conditions for a January deal are that the focus remains on long-term targets and adding real quality this month can be difficult to do.

Beefing up numbers to compensate for the lack of depth is also an issue that should ease as the month progresses. Kobbie Mainoo, Mason Mount and Bruno Fernandes should all be back fit soon and Noussair Mazraoui, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo will be back from the Africa Cup of Nations by January 19 at the latest.

But United should be and are alert to opportunities in midfield, with question marks over the futures of several key players. There is also uncertainty as to whether Mainoo will push for a loan move if his chances of first-team football don't improve over the next couple of weeks.

Joshua Zirkzee is also eyeing up a move to Roma. His departure could leave Amorim short of attacking opportunities, with Benjamin Sesko the only natural centre-forward in the squad. Finding a permanent replacement might not be easy, but adding a striker to the squad to offer support and cover for Sesko could be beneficial.

These kinds of January deals might only move the needle ever so slightly; they might only be worth a point or two come the final calculations, but in what is shaping up to be a tight race for places in the top five, that might be all it takes to make them value for money.
At the halfway stage, United have put themselves in the conversation. Now they need to do all they can to finish the job.

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United transfer stance on Toby Collyer after loan recall decision
body: Toby Collyer is set to be fit before the end of January, but the midfielder could remain at Manchester United for the rest of the season, rather than being loaned out again. The 21-year-old was officially recalled from his loan with Championship side West Brom on New Year's Day, but he has been at Carrington since the end of November after suffering a calf injury with the Baggies.

Collyer struggled for game time before suffering his injury setback, starting just three Championship games and making 12 appearances in total. After sustaining his injury, he has been undergoing rehabilitation with his parent club. He could have returned to the Hawthorns when fit, but United have made the decision to recall him from a planned season-long loan due to concerns over his playing time in the Midlands, as well as his injury issue.

The former Brighton youngster is expected to be fit again by the end of this month, having not featured competitively since sustaining a calf injury during West Brom’s 1-1 draw with Birmingham City in late November.
Collyer will be monitored now that he is back at United and could stay at the club for the remainder of the season if Ruben Amorim decides to keep him as part of the first-team squad.

The midfielder has made 13 appearances for United, 10 of which came under Amorim last season. Although United will have a light schedule in the second half of the season, there is uncertainty over the futures of Manuel Ugarte and Kobbie Mainoo in the January transfer window, with both attracting loan interest.

If Collyer plays for United this month, it would prohibit another loan move, as players can only play for two clubs during a season. If he doesn't feature, then another loan switch to play first-team football remains an option.
United face an injury crisis in midfield at the moment, but Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes are expected to be fit this month.

headline: Shea Lacey, Chido Obi - Man United's overlooked stars of the future must prove Ruben Amorim wrong
body: Manchester United have a proud history of integrating academy stars into their first-team early, often when rivals would have chosen to be more cautious. The Class of '92 are the poster boys for this movement and have shaped the United philosophy in the years which have followed.

Even as we exit 2025 and enter 2026, United are still seen as a club who give youth a chance. We only have to look back to last January and see how Ayden Heaven chose to leave Arsenal because the opportunities were readily available in the north west, to prove this theory.

However, while it may be inadvertent, Ruben Amorim seems to have forged a war with the academy players which is leading to an awkward succession line. Alejandro Garnacho was a recent academy graduate who failed to see eye-to-eye with the manager and it feels a similar situation is starting to brew with Kobbie Mainoo - albeit it is nowhere near the same level yet.

But even further down the pecking order, there is some worrying signs of a disconnect between the two levels. Earlier this month, Amorim felt the need to call out Harry Amass, currently at Sheffield Wednesday, and Chido Obi for sending subtle messages to him on Instagram.

"Sometimes strong words is not bad words, sometimes difficult moments is not the bad things for the kids," Amorim told a largely stunned press conference. "We don't need to be always with accolades in everything in every situation, we are not helping.

"That's why when you guys talk about a lot of players nowadays that they go against the clubs and everything happened because they feel entitlement. I think it's something in our club, and we talk about the players sometimes forget about what it means to play for Manchester United.

"We as a club sometimes forget who we are and that's that's the feeling that I have. I understand everything is the environment, is the moment of the players, the kids they feel entitled. They feel free to respond to the manager with a picture, my office is open, nobody is coming to talk to me."

Since then, Amorim has needed to rely on the youngsters just to fill his squad. Obi made the bench alongside Shea Lacey, Tyler Fletcher, and his twin Jack, Tyler Fredricson and Bendito Mantato. Only Jack Fletcher and Mantato were brought on to face the Premier League's worst club Wolves.
Fletcher and Fredricson's place as unused substitutes made sense considering they are a midfielder and defender respectively. But the decision to overlook Obi and Lacey was surprising.

It left many wondering why the duo were picked on the bench if they were going to be ignored when the team needs a goal, despite being attackers. Perhaps sensing a backlash, Amorim went on the offensive post-match.

"It's completely different and you know that when there is a lot of new people in different positions and you put one young kid, he will struggle," the United manager said assuredly. "It's completely different when you have a base, everything is working well and you can give minutes to a young kid.

"You look at the game and you understand clearly and you see our team and you know that you are going to struggle in certain aspects and I think that was what happened during the game." The way Amorim suggested things would go from bad to worse if he had thrown in more young players, should grate the academy stars' nerves.

They should be feeling hard done by because, regardless of the lack of options, they were first-team players on Tuesday night and when the game needed attackers, they were overlooked. That should fuel something in them now to prove Amorim wrong.

Like the United boss said in the middle of this month, this does not mean Obi and Lacey should take to Instagram to send subtle but immature messages to the manager. Instead, the objective should be to knuckle down and prove to Amorim he has misjudged their talents and they can actually be brought on to make a difference.

While United have so many players out, Amorim will need to continue using academy players on his bench. Eventually, there will come a time when the Reds' boss bites the bullet and gives them a chance to impress and just like Fletcher has done, they need to take it.

headline: Man United handed transfer green light for £61m Antoine Semenyo alternative
body: Manchester United have been handed a boost in their proposed chase for RB Leipzig forward Yan Diomande, with the club's chief Oliver Mintzlaff admitting that they could sell him if the price was right.

Diomande has been named as a possible alternative target to Antoine Semenyo for United. The Bournemouth man looks to be heading to rivals Manchester City, despite interest from United, leaving Ruben Amorim's side looking at other potential options moving forward.
While RB Leipzig will be keen to keep hold of their young talent, it's been hinted that a big offer could tempt the German club into cashing-in on his signature.
In an interview with German outlet Welt, Mintzlaff said: "We want to ensure that we don't just develop players for one year. But that we can also retain top talents for longer.

"We still see ourselves as a top club in the Bundesliga. And for young players like (Assan) Ouedraogo or Diomande, it would be good to take the next steps with us and consistently perform at a high level.

"However, it will remain the case in the future that we will occasionally have to let our players go. We still need to generate transfer fees and have players in our squad who are attractive to absolute top clubs.

"Generally speaking, you should never rule anything out in football. If there's an exorbitant offer far above market value, and we are convinced that it's a unique opportunity for a significant profit, then we have to be honest with ourselves, discuss it, and keep a cool head."
The 19-year-old is currently on Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON) duty with the Ivory Coast. So far this season, he has scored six times and provided a further three assists in 14 Bundesliga games.
United are not alone in their interest with Bayern Munich and Paris Saint-Germain also claimed to be tracking his development closely.
While the comments are seemingly positive news for United, it doesn't necessarily mean they will launch a move during the January window - or even next summer.
It's reported that United are not certain to pursue an alternative to Semenyo in the upcoming window, but could potentially accelerate their interest if other clubs do.

Instead, that might in turn be one for future windows, with eyes also on midfield targets. The position has been identified as a priority for United with names such as Nottingham Forest's Elliot Anderson, Crystal Palace's Adam Wharton and Brighton's Carlos Baleba all being linked.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund's Man United career 'is over' as club chief confirms transfer details
body: Rasmus Hojlund's permanent transfer from Manchester United to Napoli is all but confirmed, according to a top official at the Italian club. The striker was loaned to the Serie A giants for the season and has made an immediate impact.

Napoli have the option to make the move permanent for €50m (£43.6m) at the end of the loan spell, which will become mandatory if they secure a Champions League spot this season. However, all the signs point towards Hojlund making a permanent switch regardless.
Giovanni Manna, Napoli's director, has stated that both the club and Hojlund view the transfer as essentially finalised, reports the Mirror.

“We did everything we could to sign him. There were more storied clubs interested, but his will was crucial, and we are proud of it,” Manna said in an interview with Italian outlet Corriere dello Sport.
“We had no doubts. Rasmus is decisive in terms of numbers, but also in how he understands the coach’s input. This makes a difference.
“There’s an option to buy and an obligation to buy if we qualify for the Champions League. The player considers himself a Napoli player, and the same goes for us. This is extremely important.”
When quizzed about whether a permanent move for Hojlund was likely, Manna responded: “As of today, I think so.”

These remarks from Manna follow reports in Italy suggesting that Napoli are already preparing the terms of Hojlund's contract as a full-time player. Reports suggest the striker will have a €85m (£74.2m) release clause included in his contract in Naples - with that clause becoming active in the summer of 2027. Hojlund has netted seven goals in 19 appearances for the Serie A outfit this campaign.
“Hojlund is a player who is very young, he’s still only 22 years old, and can improve a great deal,” Napoli boss Antonio Conte said about Hojlund’s form recently.

“Since he first joined us, he has already progressed to become a dominant player in that role, because he’s starting to understand the right positions to take, how to defend the ball, when to come towards it or back off."

The Italian added: “He is really well connected with the team. In my style of football, the strikers have a very important and special role in the overall approach, and he has huge margin for further improvement.”

Hojlund signed for United from Atalanta in 2023, bagging 16 goals during his first campaign at Old Trafford before adding another ten in his second season, with only four of those coming in the Premier League.

headline: MARSHALL: Why Ruben Amorim changed the Manchester United formation vs Wolves
body: Ruben Amorim went back to his favoured back three system for Manchester United's Premier League clash with Wolves to try and counter the approach from the Premier League's basement boys. Amorim finally moved to a back four against Newcastle on Boxing Day and saw his side win 1-0, with a much more fluent attacking performance in the first half. But with winless Wolves at Old Trafford, he opted for a safety-first approach and sought to match Wolves' system.

United were missing eight players through injuries or international call-ups, but produced a flat performance against a team that had taken just two points from their first 18 Premier League games of the season. Joshua Zirkzee's deflected shot gave them the lead, but Ladislav Krejci equalised before half-time and the visitors came closest to winning the game.
Amorim admitted his change in system was based on his evaluation of Wolves and that he moved Patrick Dorgu back to wing-back to try and take advantage of that.

"We knew that they will play with a five, use the width, today was to do that and sometimes build up with him [Dorgu] open or close with Luke doing the opposite, we try to arrange the right situations," said Amorim.

It didn't work and although United were missing key players in Harry Maguire, Matthijs de Ligt, Noussair Mazraoui, Amad, Kobbie Mainoo, Bruno Fernandes, Mason Mount and Bryan Mbeumo, Amorim refused to use those absences as an excuse, but admitted he knew why his side had struggled.
"That is normal but we didn't use that excuse against Newcastle, we are not going to use it today," he said. "But of course if you see the game I understand why we play the way we play today.

"The lack of fluidity, lack of one against one. We knew that would be a completely different game compared to Newcastle because in Newcastle we have more space to play. We didn't have to work the plays so much and today we have."

headline: What Ruben Amorim did vs Wolves makes Man United January transfer priority clear
body: "We need to do what the game was asking," was the beginning of Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim's staunch defence of his decision to take Joshua Zirkzee off at half time during the draw with Wolverhampton Wanderers. For a man who was once cheered off the pitch by United supporters, it is now fitting for Zirkzee that his exit on Tuesday baffled everyone.

But Zirkzee was not injured and Amorim was keen to defend his decision to bring on Jack Fletcher and solidify the midfield further. "They put a lot of men in the middle of the park and with Jack we balanced that," Amorim continued.

"I think we recovered the ball faster in the second half. In the first half we struggled a little bit to recover the ball so I'm just looking not for their age and experience and in this moment I just look at what I can do to win the game."

Sadly for Amorim, his excuse for hauling Zirkzee off was flimsy at best. While the Dutchman may have been fortunate to score the opener, he was at least providing a threat for United. At that stage of the match, with United still needing a goal, taking off a forward for a midfielder was not the option. The optics were terrible and while Fletcher did well when he was introduced into the game, Benjamin Sesko, Patrick Dorgu and Matheus Cunha did not muster up nearly enough going forward to win the match for the Reds.

Ultimately, substituting Zirkzee at half time is a clear sign of what the future holds for United heading into the January transfer window. Amorim seems destined to allow the Dutchman to depart next month and there seems very little the 24-year-old can do to change his mind.

Since the Reds invested in the attack during the summer transfer window, Zirkzee has been on borrowed time. Rasmus Hojlund was perhaps wise to jump at the opportunity to leave for Napoli upon the arrival of Sesko.
Like Hojlund, Zirkzee is not a player who Amorim sees fitting the system. The glimmer of hope for the forward's United career was him being able to gain more chances while there was absentees.

What Tuesday night proved is that this route is not available to Zirkzee either. It is understood AS Roma have a keen interest in bringing Zirkzee back to Serie A and a return to Italy is the best option for him, especially if he wants to make a late bid for the Netherlands national team in a World Cup year.

As for Amorim and United, the pressure is on. If Zirkzee is to leave in January, they must look to replace him with a recognised striker. The United boss has spoken at length about his desire to sign players who can benefit the club in the future, not just the present. But how many of those centre-forwards are available and fit the bill in January?

All the pressure is on the powers that be at Old Trafford now because if the substitution against Wolves is a sign of Zirkzee's impending exit, they will be expected to adequately replace him. Waiting for the summer is simply not an option for the Reds when the attack is wafer thin already.
